title: Future Returns: How TPG’s Rise Fund Invests in Energy
text:
Text size

The energy sector investments sought by TPG's The Rise Fund fall across several themes aimed at reducing the harmful emissions that contribute to climate change and at making affordable, reliable, sustainable energy widely available.

At US$2.1 billion, Rise is the world’s biggest private-equity fund investing for impact. Since 2017, the global fund has invested in more than 25 growth-stage companies that are making a measurable positive social and/or environmental impact. TPG also recently closed on US$1.2 billion for a second Rise Fund that’s expected to eventually total about US$3 billion. That includes $500 million in assets from The Evercare Health Fund, which TPG purchased last June.

Rise's investments fall across seven sectors, including agriculture, education, and healthcare. For energy, a major part of the strategy is to find companies across the globe working to reduce or mitigate the effects of greenhouse gas emissions on the climate, says Rick Needham, energy sector lead for the fund.

That means focusing on companies addressing “three main pillars of decarbonization”: low carbon energy, energy efficiency, and electrification, Needham says.

In addition, Rise seeks to invest in companies that can provide energy to the billion consumers in developing markets who don’t have access to electricity and the three billion who cook over open flames.

Needham spoke with Penta recently about the fund’s strategy for investing in alternative energy.

Investing in Decarbonization

In June 2018, Rise invested US$70 million in Fourth Partner Energy, a distributed energy company in Hyderabad, India, that offers commercial, industrial, and public-sector rooftop solar systems.

“One big theme in the energy space is decentralization,” Needham says. “From a market perspective, those distributed assets will sometimes sell at prices higher than utility-scale projects.”

Building out distributed solar systems at scale can be tough, but Rise was attracted to Fourth Partner because of its success with blue-chip customers like Pepsi, Nestle and Schneider Electric, he says.

Fourth Partner also “had great customer focus, and was delivering the kinds of savings and energy that the customers were promised, such as almost every customer they had was a repeat customer that kept coming back,” Needham says.

The investment in Fourth Partner meets Rise's goal of financing low-carbon projects, while its June 2018 purchase of CLEAResult in Austin, Texas—a co-investment with TPG—meets its goal to invest in energy efficiency. (Financial terms of the acquisition from General Atlantic, a global growth equity firm, were not disclosed).

CLEAResult serves residential, institutional, commercial, and industrial utility customers across the U.S. with energy-efficiency services and programs. The firm also provides demand response technology, which allows customers to turn off energy-intensive appliances during times of peak energy demand.

“They will be shifting even more so into things like beneficial electrification, electric vehicle charging, storage—all these things that don’t just provide energy efficiency, but provide utilities the ability not only to lower demand, but also to manage it by time and location,” Needham says.

This is “a general theme that’s happening in the energy world too—as more renewables get deployed, flexibility becomes key, and the ability to manage [energy use] by time and location is becoming more important.”

Why Rise Hasn’t Invested in Electrification...Yet

In electrification, the third pillar of Rise's decarbonization strategy, the firm is looking at transportation—electric vehicles, in other words—as well as industrial processes.

“If you were to shift those over to electrification, then in the process of decarbonizing your grid, you are also decarbonizing those processes which originally were liquid-fuel based,” Needham says.

While the fund has looked hard at a “mobility” company in the electrification space, Rise didn’t invest as interest from other investors pushed the valuation too high. The situation is a classic problem in impact investing, Needham says. “In these cases, we find an interesting company, but there are other investors, [who are] maybe not as hard nosed about the kind of returns we want to find for our investors.”

This is particularly true in electric vehicles, where a large amount of investment is being funneled into companies Rise considers unproven. A few companies have valuations in the hundreds of millions, or even US$1 billion, and “don’t have a vehicle on the road,” Needham says.

The fund is also wary of electric vehicle companies because of expected future competition in the sector. “Battery prices have been declining 80% or so since 2010, so the economics of these vehicles are getting better and better,” he says. “Within a few years they will be nearly cost-competitive with an [internal combustion] engine vehicle.”

The potential competition is widespread and global. “Even though it’s not yet at a scale, it’s at a projected scale and a projected inflection point that’s coming,” Needham says.

Energy Access

TPG also has yet to find the right investment in energy access. The problem is finding a company that has the scale to handle the size investment the fund would make (typically at least US$50 million to US$150 million), Needham says.

Also, it’s been difficult to find companies with a proven ability to run a good, profitable business that can scale, he says.

One reason Rise avoids making small investments is that the fund becomes actively involved with the companies it invests in, helping them to grow, Needham says. “If we had a portfolio that was too large, we wouldn’t be able to live up to that promise of delivering that.”
description: The world’s largest impact investing fund is focusing on decarbonization and energy access
